question.title: Using an external .cfg file instead of defining Property files at build time

node.contents:
We are using a blueprint, we called it camel-context.xml but it has 
<blueprint>
  in it. All it is doing is Creating a controller bean and exporting it to the service registry (per the comments). Edited main post and added it.
</blueprint>

node.contents: I think I'm able to share some experiences on this, but first may I ask - are you using a `blueprint.xml` in your project? Otherwise how are you configuring your camel routes.

astNode.text: I think I'm able to share some experiences on this, but first may I ask - are you using a `blueprint.xml` in your project? Otherwise how are you configuring your camel routes.

node.contents: Our project is using Apache Camel, with FuseESB and we are also utilizing Spring. Right now we have a handful of property files that we define when we build the project (with Maven).

astNode.text: Our project is using Apache Camel, with FuseESB and we are also utilizing Spring. Right now we have a handful of property files that we define when we build the project (with Maven).

node.contents: We want to move the property files to an external file that will be on each system (dev/qa/prod) and use that as the property file.

astNode.text: We want to move the property files to an external file that will be on each system (dev/qa/prod) and use that as the property file.

node.contents: I'm trying to figure out how I am going to do this. There is more of course but this is relevant to the question I believe. I was looking at the Camel documentation but I'm still a little bit confused on how to go about this.

astNode.text: I'm trying to figure out how I am going to do this. There is more of course but this is relevant to the question I believe. I was looking at the Camel documentation but I'm still a little bit confused on how to go about this.

node.contents: I was looking at this post at the question, and it seemed that I want to use that type of configuration but in my Spring xml file.

astNode.text: I was looking at this post at the question, and it seemed that I want to use that type of configuration but in my Spring xml file.

node.contents: I just need some general guidance with this, Thanks!

astNode.text: I just need some general guidance with this, Thanks!

node.contents: You can check out my answer on the following thread. There's a fully detailed example. It uses Spring DM for property loading (easy way for doing this). This solution will extend your PropertyPlaceHolder with the properties found in OSGi. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16984812/proxy-authentication-with-camel-using-producertemplate/16985136#16985136.

astNode.text: You can check out my answer on the following thread. There's a fully detailed example. It uses Spring DM for property loading (easy way for doing this). This solution will extend your PropertyPlaceHolder with the properties found in OSGi. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16984812/proxy-authentication-with-camel-using-producertemplate/16985136#16985136.

node.contents: @envinyater Also check out this link for Spring-DM http://static.springsource.org/osgi/docs/1.2.x/reference/html/compendium.html - But try to use Blueprint if possible :)

astNode.text: @envinyater Also check out this link for Spring-DM http://static.springsource.org/osgi/docs/1.2.x/reference/html/compendium.html - But try to use Blueprint if possible :)

node.contents: Will this replace the propertyplaceholder in the spring xml file -- should I remove that part now?

astNode.text: Will this replace the propertyplaceholder in the spring xml file -- should I remove that part now?

node.contents: I was able to get this to work very nicely. Thank you.

astNode.text: I was able to get this to work very nicely. Thank you.

node.contents: For external configuration you want to be looking at OSGI cm property-placeholders;

astNode.text: For external configuration you want to be looking at OSGI cm property-placeholders;

node.contents: There is some information about this here

astNode.text: There is some information about this here

node.contents: To override the default properties defined within your cm:property-placeholder block you provide an external file which matches the unique persistent-id attribute value you provided with a file type of '.cfg'.

astNode.text: To override the default properties defined within your cm:property-placeholder block you provide an external file which matches the unique persistent-id attribute value you provided with a file type of '.cfg'.

node.contents: If you are wanting to deploy to Karaf for instance; Then this config will be dropped into ${KARAF_HOME}/etc/yourPID.cfg

astNode.text: If you are wanting to deploy to Karaf for instance; Then this config will be dropped into ${KARAF_HOME}/etc/yourPID.cfg

node.contents: This capability is provided with both Spring DM and Blueprint

astNode.text: This capability is provided with both Spring DM and Blueprint

node.contents: You could also look at setting up a Fuse Fabric.

astNode.text: You could also look at setting up a Fuse Fabric.

node.contents: Instead of editing .cfg files manually, each server (container) in the fabric is configured with a specified profile. For example, myprofile-dev, myprofile-qa, myprofile-prod.

astNode.text: Instead of editing .cfg files manually, each server (container) in the fabric is configured with a specified profile. For example, myprofile-dev, myprofile-qa, myprofile-prod.

node.contents: This will insert the properties (e.g. foo=bar) from the fabric profile right into the cm property-placeholders, and your blueprint configuration will be mostly the same as described by AlanFoster in his answer.

astNode.text: This will insert the properties (e.g. foo=bar) from the fabric profile right into the cm property-placeholders, and your blueprint configuration will be mostly the same as described by AlanFoster in his answer.

node.contents: Here's some info on Fabric Profiles.

astNode.text: Here's some info on Fabric Profiles.

node.contents: Especially if you are running many servers and environments, fabric profiles can be a nice way to manage deployment and configuration.

astNode.text: Especially if you are running many servers and environments, fabric profiles can be a nice way to manage deployment and configuration.

node.contents: Note that I'm not completely sure how this solves your spring vs blueprint issue. I chose to do away with spring completely, and move all the DI & beans into blueprint, avoiding the spring vs blueprint conflict and leaving the configuration of properties exclusively in blueprint.

astNode.text: Note that I'm not completely sure how this solves your spring vs blueprint issue. I chose to do away with spring completely, and move all the DI & beans into blueprint, avoiding the spring vs blueprint conflict and leaving the configuration of properties exclusively in blueprint.

node.contents: I'm not sure if you want to do away with spring or not - perhaps you would prefer to keep it, in which case can I suggest looking at the section Bridging Spring and Camel property holders down towards the bottom of the page at this link: Camel: Using Property Placeholder (haven't tried it myself, ymmv).

astNode.text: I'm not sure if you want to do away with spring or not - perhaps you would prefer to keep it, in which case can I suggest looking at the section Bridging Spring and Camel property holders down towards the bottom of the page at this link: Camel: Using Property Placeholder (haven't tried it myself, ymmv).

node.contents: Good luck!

astNode.text: Good luck!
